Our puppy got crate trained within a week! As has been said above you need to make them want to go in the crate and make them enjoy it.
We don't give our dog his food until he goes and sits in his crate, then we shut the door while he eats then open it once he's done.
Also our crate is quite big, half is taken up by his bed and half is a folded towel with his toys in it. We've also folded a blanket over the bed side of the crate so it's like a cave so he can have privacy when he goes to bed, but he can go to the towel end when he wants to see out.
When we would first put him in we would sit on the floor just outside it so he could see we're not far away. Now his crate stays at the end of the living room where he has a clear view of us.
Also, if you use clicker training a good technique is one of you hold your dog so it can't run, the other one excitedly call the puppy over and put tasty treats in the crate so the dog WANTS to go in, the person lets go, the dog excitedly goes in to get a treat, you click the clicker and praise him, then repeat!

WRITING.TITLE: Jackbox 3: party pack is so fun!
WRITING.TEXT:
I downloaded this on a whim yesterday as my neighbours came over and we were looking for something to do. My neighbours typically go to bed fairly early (10ish), but we put this on for "one game" before they left and they ended up staying another 2 hours, leaving at midnight!
To sum up how it works, you press play on your chosen game mode and a 4 letter code appears. Every player then goes to jackbox.tv on any internet connected device and puts in the code and their name/icon. Your smart device then works as your buzzer/drawing pad, etc. It's 2-8 players, and the mechanics of each game are different.
The game flows well and the announcer announces what you do very smoothly such that you feel like you could be watching an actual TV quiz show.
I looked at this game for a few days before deciding to take the plunge (20) but I'm glad I did. If you like cards against humanity, drinking games or general quizzes then I'd recommend this!

My point is that after a first mass school shooting there should never be a second, not the semantics of whether there were 200 or 198 school shootings.

It being in a strict gun control state is virtually irrelevant when you don't have policed borders between states? Guns are so widely available their black market value is low compared to countries with complete gun prohibition.
The last school shooting (as far as I'm aware) we had in the UK was [dunblane](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunblane_school_massacre), which was 1996 and, as a result, we virtually banned private gun ownership and there hasn't been a school shooting since, and there's only been one (as far as I'm aware) mass shooting since, which was in Cumbria in 2010.
Whereas in the US there have been (at the time of this article) [over 200 school shootings](https://everytownresearch.org/school-shootings/) since 2013.
Obviously your country is bigger and there are a whole host of socio-economic factors at play, but it's ludicrous to an outsider that in the face of the huge gun crime problem you don't massively clamp down on guns.
Obviously, there are so many in circulation it's hard, but the key to combating that is imposing a tougher sentence for having a banned gun and having an amnesty. We had a school stabbing so the police held a [knife amnesty](https://www.google.co.uk/amp/www.independent.co.uk/news/police-knife-amnesty-nets-40000-weapons-1325322.html%3Famp) where 40,000 knifes/swords were handed in with no questions asked and no fear of reprisal.

People can join IS in many forms other than travelling to the heart of IS country, presumably. It's more commonplace when you see follow up news after they commit atrocities to see them say it was a splinter cell who did it, who received training and funding in other countries, not in the countries you'd typically associate with IS.
Plus, it's naive to assume no new people are getting in to the epicentre or IS - where there's a will, money and corruption, people will always be able to travel around. It's why human trafficking is still happening, even in countries like the UK and the USA.

It's not that we wouldn't _want_ them to go out fighting - it's that there are more eventualities than them keeping living out there and then dying fighting out there.
It's the same reason lawyers and police offer reduced sentences and plea deals even when they know somebody has done something.
The most dangerous people are those who have nothing to lose, so if people want rehabilitation and you categorically rule that out, it means anyone who has even just made a mistake and flown to a country to join Isis but who hasn't even yet picked up a gun or done anything hateful/terroristic has no way out and is left to see their mistake through.

As with other points people have made on this thread - I don't disagree with you, and I fully see the logic in your stance.
Unfortunately the reality is not so black and white. Not all IS fighters are front line jihadi "soldiers" and so they won't all be shot and an easily taken care of problem. There are tacticians, bomb makers, wives of jihadis who hold emotional sway over fighters, etc. If a bomb maker, for example, saw error in his way, he might prefer a "fair" sentence in an American jail followed by a life in the US post-jail as opposed to living out his days in Mosul. And one guy choosing to stop making bombs could theoretically save hundreds of lives.
As I said before, also in this thread, I also used to have such clear views in my head, however my life experience has taught me that if you don't bend and provide small allowances for things, then they break and completely fall apart. No stance is immune to criticism, no plan is infallible.

WRITING.TITLE: How to select what data to download off of firebase?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hi guys,
In a nutshell I have data stored on firebase than I want to randomly distribute, but in order of when it was submitted. For example:
People upload data (let's say a voice clip), I want to set it so on the app there's a download button and when a user hits it it checks for the voice clip at the front of the queue, checks it's not uploaded by the current user, if not it downloads the voice clip and adds "1" to the counter, and once the counter reaches 5 the voice clip is then put into a waiting bay, pending all 5 users who downloaded it rating it, whereby an action is taken.
I ask this as I've just realised that all logic needs undertaken at the front end and not the back end, so I'm trying to implement the sorting of voice clips in line with the download button.
When a user uploads an audio clip I'm thinking of having firebase store:
1. The clip 2. Clip name 3. Date 4. User Unique ID number 5. Username 6. Number of downloads (set to zero initially) 7. Score
Is the best way to tell firebase to look for the oldest date? And then check that the user id doesn't equal current user idea, and then if a suitable clip is found +1 to number of downloads?
Any input to this very general question would be appreciated!

Is goat simulator a 10 because it's the best goat simulation game there's ever been? Probably not.

No, but is Nintendogs literally the BEST it could physically be, aka 10/10? Is there zero scope for improvement?
A game like Zelda is much more open to interpretation as it has a story and gameplay elements. A game as simple as Nintendogs - whilst still able to feasibly achieve a 10 would, in my opinion, have to do a lot more to be classed as perfect.
I'm not comparing Nintendogs to Zelda like for like, I'm saying look at Zelda whilst considering the boundaries of RPG/adventure games and look at Nintendogs within the context of its' genre - are both games equally as accomplished/pushing the boundaries? In my opinion - no.

WRITING.TITLE: Sneaky Tesco pushing back release date
WRITING.TEXT:
I ordered from Tesco on day one of pre orders as they guaranteed release day delivery.
I just checked my order and it says releasing 6th of March so I phoned them. The guy on the phone said "yes, release day delivery - the console is dropping on the 6th of March."
I said "no, the console is dropping on the 3rd of March?"
He said "no, we have a staff notice that Nintendo are dropping it on the 6th and they'll do an announcement on the 6th telling everyone."
I said "I highly doubt they're pushing the release date back 3 days and aren't telling anyone until 3 days after the fact. Plus amazon, Argos, etc all still say the third."
He said "oh well there's nothing more I can tell you than what it says here."
What it looks like is that Tesco want to ensure release day delivery so they've just created their own release date, 3 days after Nintendos actual release date. I'm going to be left with BoTW and no console to play it on.
TL:DR; Tesco can eat a great big bowl of dicks.

They said it's to keep numbers down! I'm not annoyed at my friend, and I'm certainly not hurt, I just feel it's a huge ask for me to go solo when it'll cost so much, and possibly hurt my gf's feelings.
Also, I already booked the double hotel room when I thought I had a plus one, so the groom thinks I'm coming so if I now send the confirmation back with "I will not be attending" after he's told me I don't have a plus one I don't want it to seem spiteful!

They said it was to limit numbers they only invited plus ones they've met or know quite well!
They've met my girlfriend twice, like 6 years apart, so they know we've been together at least that long.
As I said to somebody above, it's their special day so they can and can't invite who they like, but I agree with you, we've been together long enough that she could realistically be my wife.

I do agree with you and have personally ran through that train of thought in my head, but when I did the counter arguments I came up with myself were:
1. Yes, weddings are expensive. But the main expense is the venue, the rings, the cake, the band, etc. None of which get more expensive per guest. The additional cost for having plus ones there would be that of the meal, which they'll more than make back in wedding gifts. Plus, I guarantee it'd cost me a lot more for me and my girlfriend to go, than it'd cost them to have us there.
2. I do 100% agree it's their day and their rules, I have no hard feelings at all that my girlfriend isn't invited, I'm just trying to figure out if I should still go despite that. There'd be absolutely no love lost between me and my friend even if I don't go (on my end, anyway)!
3. I guess yes, I can physically afford the grand it'll cost. It would have to come out of my savings and will be a Grand I don't spend on something else, however. I had no qualms with paying the grand (I've already prebooked double rooms at the hotel and meals, when I assumed I had a plus one), but I just can't justify going myself I don't think! At least if me and my SO could make a long weekend of it, it'd be like a nice weekend for us too, justifying the spend.
4. Me and my gf have been together 8 years and lived together for, like, 5. I'm pretty sure that's longer/more than the bride and groom at this wedding. Not inviting my gf would be like not inviting someone's wife. Even if she wouldn't say it I think it would hurt my GF's feelings if I went.

It's not like a wedding abroad, but the hotel is ~ $160 a night, and it would be two nights. Travel there would be $100, alcohol and food would be expensive, wedding gift would be expensive, etc.
And yeah, I got the save the date in a postcard form so it just had my name on it, but I assumed that was because it was a post card and you don't typically address post cards to two people. However, my actual invite came later and it just had my name on it so I asked my friend and he confirmed it was limited numbers and just me invited.

For anyone wondering I got to the bottom of this using:
UserDefaults.standard.set(input.text, forKey: "username")
I set the above code to the push of a button, making what text was in the "input" text box globally accessible.
I then went to the view controller I needed the label to appear and called the userdefault text string.
Much easier than what I previously tried to do by pushing the text to each view controller in turn with the segue.

Agreed it shouldn't be given out this way, but why should it be the universal minimum?
Say you wait 6 tables in an hour and each tips you this universal minimum, you've just made $30/hour. If you did this minimum each hour, not including your base salary, you'd be getting 60k a year. Obviously in some restaurants they split tips, but also on average I'm sure you'd do more than 6 tables and if this was the universal minimum you'd also get more from most customers, so the $30/hour figure isn't too far off.

In a country where servers get normal wages and *optional* tips. Can confirm food is not exponentially more expensive.
Also, can confirm servers don't give shitty service because service is their job and what they're paid their normal wage to do. If they regularly gave shit service they'd very quickly find themselves without a job.

Not necessarily, somebody could still just order one plate but it could be a much more expensive meal due to ingredients but no more work on your part.

Not really, as it doesn't benefit any company. The guy who lowered restaurant wages to compensate is the real marketing genius.

Disagree with you on many fronts here:
1. Tipping isn't a big thing here in the U.K. And our cost of eating out is pretty in line with yours, so I doubt paying a little more would push prices up. Yes, if just one restaurant tried to pay more they'd try push their prices up to compensate. But if the whole system changed and did it, as soon as one restaurant tried to push their prices up then people would just eat elsewhere.
Plus, if you're expecting like 20% tips then there's a pretty big margin there for food to get more expensive and cost the consumer no more than they're paying anyway.
2. Good / bad service shouldn't mean your reward is scaled. If you're good at your job the reward should be keeping your job, if you're fundamentally bad at your job, you probably shouldn't have that job.
Also, your point that it creates accountability isn't true where the culture is also such that you're expected to tip regardless. Bad service should = no tip if this were to work. I had a post in /AskReddit about tipping and one guy said even when he gets poor service he feels too guilty to not tip.

Yeah I'm Scottish. The process was alright, actually. I tried to get a place like 2 years ago and was turned down because I had no credit history - I.e. I'd never been in debt in my life, which means they were unsure if I'd be able to handle debt. It's quite silly as having never been in debt, it should show that I can handle my finances. So I bought a motorbike on credit and paid it off over a year to raise my credit rating. After that I had to make sure I had a deposit (10% of mortgage value) + 3k for lawyers fees etc, then I was good to go. Saw one place I fell in love with, shmoozed the seller a bit, put in an offer and negotiated for her to leave a lot of furniture and here I am a year later!
Interest rate at the moment here is quite low, I got mine at 2.7%. I took a 30 year mortgage and repayments are initially weighted as a lot more interest than actual repayments, but if I overpay by 40% or so every month it'll bring my mortgage down by 15 years, so I sit that extra money aside every month to make sure nothing crops up (like redundancy!) and then pay it at the end of each year, or so the plan is.
Yeah, all my previous flats I rented have been white walled, beige carpeted ones too. The week I got my keys myself and my girlfriend came in and stripped all the wallpaper and painted the shit out of the place! I also tried my hand at building a big (8 metre +) flower planted in the back garden!
If you were worried about repaying you could always get a two bed and rent out a room?

Yeah, I love it! I rented with a friend before so it was fun having a room mate, but I was paying 400 a month rent and trying to save 1000 a month towards an apartment - now I own a place I just need to pay my mortgage (which is essentially money in the bank, minus the large interest) and save a lot less!
Also, it's fun being able to paint it decorate however you want! And just knowing you own a home is pretty nice!
I lost my job like 3 months after I got my flat, so that was a tiny bit stressful but I got a new one pretty quickly so that was lucky - would've been screwed if I couldn't get one in the longer term!
I'd say the pros are everything except that it sort of ties you down and means you need a recurring income for the next 25/30 years without exception, which is quite daunting!
Since we were chatting on my post I checked out some of yours - what did you decide regarding house buying? I jumped onto the property ladder exactly a year ago! Got sick of renting!

So, a question:
If you could get paid, say, $15 an hour but nobody tipped, or $2 an hour but you had to rely on tips - which would you choose?
And I do agree completely with what you're saying. It just seems like when you're saying "when you tip you need to factor in how hard I work, how hard chefs work, how hard bartenders work" the phrase "when you tip" should be substituted for "when your employer pays you" - in literally every other job and industry your paid based/promoted based on your effort and typically harder/better workers earn more.
Also, the service industry is one of the only industries where tipping in generally expected.
Why is it that a server deserves a tip for doing their job but a cashier at a store doesn't, or your garbage man doesn't, etc? Other than saying your wages are low, which is surely your employers responsibility, not your customers?
Not arguing, by the way, just trying to get a servers thoughts on these things!

Thanks for the informative and balanced answer!
Don't get me wrong, I do think American servers should get good tips (in U.K. they earn the same wages as everybody else in similar industries so it's not so vital here), but it was specifically the percentage thing I was asking about. From your example above it sounds like you deserved $30+ tip. But say you were generally happy with 20% tips, in your above example 20% would have still only been $16 for 5 hours for 2 people, aka $1.60 per person per hour. Shouldn't tips just be a lump sum based on performance, effort, time etc, it shouldn't factor in what the customer specifically ate or drank (except quantity, which again would come under time and effort)?
Also, I'm sure you are lovely, but when servers always mention how they ask about people's day, ask how they are, etc - that's just common courtesy, something I've done in every job I've ever had and in general life. You shouldn't feel that you should be reimbursed for talking to your customers?

When kuja becomes trance kuja and is standing on that rock. If you've played FF9 you'll know the scene.
I can still hear that tune in my head!

I semi see where you're coming from, except yeah, it's the customers who foot the bill - plus, your analogy is slightly off as a good salesman will bring in customers and maximise sales - it's not like servers are outside the restaurant roping you in, and other than dessert or sides it's not like they up-sell:
"I'll have a burger" "Are you suuuuure you don't want the lobster and caviar?"
It just seems so weird to me that servers can be annoyed at customers for not supplementing their income as opposed to being annoyed at their employer for paying them $2 an hour.
Plus, even then, what's the minimum wage in America (I honestly have no idea, let's assume it's $8). So if you serve 6 customers in an hour and each tipped $1, you'd be up at earning minimum wage - why do servers assume they should earn much more than that? Is being a server a massively more complex/difficult job than comparable minimum wage jobs such as grocery store employee, a cleaner, etc?

But then why do you tip at all if they're not attentive or absentee? If the service wasn't good what are you actually tipping them for? If you paid a guy to wash your car and he brought it to you dirty you wouldn't pay him, let alone tip him?

I completely get that - my question is specifically related to gauging a "good" vs "bad" tip as a percentage of your customers spend.
Like, say you spent ten mins on two customers where one had a much more expensive meal but both customers tipped $10. Would you be annoyed at the guy who had the expensive meal if that wasn't a high percentage of his total bill?

I was listening to a podcast today and it had some waitresses who were annoyed their customers were "only" tipping 15%.
It got me thinking - that's a completely arbitrary scale to go by? Like whether a guy orders a $50 steak or a $5 omelette or whatever, your job as a server involves saying hi, asking what he wants, taking it to him and saying bye - why do you feel you deserve $10 from steak guy and $1 from omelette guy (provided you're happy with 20% tip) for the exact same service?
Of course it might be a gauge of how well off the customer is financially, or just what they fancied eating that day, but again, none of that is your concern as a server?

I use ableton but I imagine it's the same for most DAWs - I think launch pads are optimised for ableton but there will be others.
Essentially you can set each part of your track to a different button on the midi controller and then when you press them it triggers the corresponding sample/clip. It's like having loads of different play buttons. And if you get one with knobs / sliders then you can start midi mapping things like volume, eq etc

What software do you use? What kind of laptop do you have?! You could get something like a launchpad or other midi controller then just assign parts of your tracks to different buttons so you're launching them sequentially so you're not just faking. I disagree - in the day and age of YouTube nobody has an excuse to not be able to maintain minor house problems. And as long as the city isn't in decline, real estate is money in the bank. Plus the money he's saving on (for example) $1000 a month rent is more than any stocks would give on a monthly basis.
At university I owned a car and I rented, the combined expense of those was huge. Then I graduated, had to pay rent for like 5 more years until I saved for a deposit for a house. If I'd have gotten on the properly ladder in first year university I'd have easily saved ~ 50k in rent.
And the things I'm advising may not be essential now, but they are in the long run, and provided the market doesn't crashC a house is an investment in itself.

Not necessarily - my degree, for example, was very specific to work in one city.
Plus, I'm advocating getting on the property ladder whilst he has a lot of liquid cash, it means he won't be paying rent for his whole college career (provided he's not currently at home), plus if he is he could rent the house out for income, or live in it and sell it and purchase a new one should he choose to move house down the line.
At university I had a car and it was pretty much a necessity for where I lived.

I never had any debt at all until I was 26. I lived by your dads rule and it always served me well. All my friends racked up thousands and thousands on student loans (that they didn't need, it was just for a better student experience) and they're still paying them now.
However, the only reason I have debt now is because I went to apply for a mortgage and physically couldn't as I was a ghost in the eyes of banks. So I bought a motorbike (I could afford in cash) on credit just to build up a credit score and now I have a mortgage.
My advice would be don't buy things you can't afford, but even when you can, use a credit card and repay it instantly just so you build a consistent credit score.

I phoned her and asked why she lied, she hung up (she's in her 50s/60s btw) and then my phone rang and it was her son saying we're lying and to stop accusing his mum because she definitely didn't say the bulbs were out.

1. He wasn't there. 2. Both myself and my girlfriend were there. 3. Why does she even have an unwired light and light switch in that room if not for the purpose of tricking perspective buyers?

I'm not sure if such a thing exists. It'd entail the software being able to individually identify all the separate instruments that make up a song (which can be difficult when they occur simultaneously), and then it would need to specifically identify the frequency of each note.
Bearing in mind when a computer "sees" a song it'll see a single wavetable, what you're speaking about would entail accurately dissecting this into its individual components, like unbaking a cake back into its constituent ingredients.

You could try layering your existing effect with a second sound using an effects rack, perhaps using a different wave type?
Or, you could modify the sound of the one you have using filters/other audio effects?
Another thing you could try is recording the progression you have as an audio clip and reversing it for a trippy effect where the brief tail of your stab them becomes a ramp up.

I'd say watch some of the chain smokers or Martin garrix videos on YouTube - can't remember the channel name, it's "future" something.
They take presets as a starting point and modify them using audio effects and make them their own. That's probably the best of both worlds in terms of giving you a starting point but also scope to change it up!

What I'm trying to say is, I'm not speaking about transphobic people who would flip about and become violent, nor am I speaking about trans allies who are fully accepting and understanding.
There is a middle ground of people who are nice to everybody regardless of sex, race, sexuality, but perhaps who would not choose to have sex with a trans person knowingly.
Let's not forget that the definition of a bigot is someone intolerant of people who hold different opinions - which in this case, would be you.
To some people a transgender persons gender is open to interpretation - genetically you're born one way, emotionally you're born another - it's not your decision which camp they fall into, although in an ideal world everyone should be accepting.
I think my ramblings can best be summarised by what someone said above: the key to informed consent is all parties being informed.
That means you're not a Paedo - can still be a Perv.

It's not at all like that, though. The underlying issue is that not everybody views trans people as their preferred gender - whether that's right or wrong is another issue. But it means that, without disclosure of their trans status, a man could find out he's just unknowingly had sex with a "man" (mtf transgender) - which would make him feel like he's just had gay sex.
This isn't something that I agree with, but you have to appreciate that everybody has different moral stand points.
It's akin to telling a devout Christian you've legally married them to have sex with them but you didn't actually file the correct paperwork. Sure, both sides are having consensual sex and may enjoy it, but finding out about something after the fact could cause somebody extreme emotional distress.
I think it's hugely important that everybody accepts trans people for who they are, but it's equally important that trans people accept that not everybody does and that it's their decision to make. I'm not saying you need to go about telling everyone, but surely if you're about to have sex with someone they deserve to make an informed decision?

Yeah I see your point. Not trying to patronise you, but is this the first time you've lived with a roommate (who isn't a family member)? I wouldn't worry about your lack of friends; I'd say out of my 20 closest friends maybe only 1 or 2 are from when I was your age, the rest came from university onwards.
For your attention span problem, that's something you'll need to work on yourself - set goals, small at first with achievable targets, and visualise the steps you'll need to take to achieve them.
In terms of worrying about money - you're 14, most 14 year olds have very little money (pocket money, minimum wage part time job, etc). It's good you have a goal (youtube), but perhaps you need to acknowledge that at 14 you're not going to have loads of cash and, instead, use that as motivation to become more goal orientated so that in future you get a high paying job.

To be fair in this situation it sounds like you're being quite petulant - maybe the actual temperature change would annoy you, but a monthly expense change of $14 is very little and, presumably, in the long run you're saving a lot more by halving the rent? Also, trying to tell someone how many plugs to have in is pretty OTT - who sets the limit at what's acceptable? What if they came into your room and saw you had 3 plugged in and told you to cut it down to 2, etc?
